Fantastic news! USDA has reinstated the summer feeding program until the end of the semester (dependent on availability of federal funds) to aid families during these unprecedented times!

Beginning Wednesday, 9/2/20, any child age 0-18, may receive a free breakfast and lunch at any Hawkins County School, whether in-person or leaning online. Children do not have to be present in the vehicle. Under this program, children do not have to be enrolled in HCS.

Meals will be available for pickup from 11:30am-12:30pm Monday - Friday at most schools (Keplar, McPheeter’s Bend and St. Clair Elementary Schools will serve pickups from 11-11:30am). Meals will not be available on September 7th due to the Labor Day holiday. Pickup times may be updated on the district website as needed.

We will continue meal service via our drive through feeding program at the identified six school site locations, daily, Mondays through Fridays from 11:30-1:00.

We will continue to support our students through our teachers' efforts and those of our instructional assistants who are calling and maintaining contact during this closure.

The Central Office and all services associated with central operations, will work split shifts, maintaining communication via email and phone calls. When not present at the office, employees will be working remotely from home in adherence to the President's recommendations. The office will be closed on Wednesdays for cleaning.

Thank you for your patience and understanding,
Matt Hixson

As part of the requirements of the G.I.V.E. Grant award to the Five Rivers Partnership for Future Ready Pathways, each school system in the partnership committed to help expand work-based learning experiences in many ways. One of those ways is through exposing non-traditional students, in this case females, to career pathways in the manufacturing industry.

To that end, a group of female cosmetology students from Volunteer High School toured the facilities of Miyake Forging North America earlier today. Barry Reeves, General Manager of the Phipp's Bend Miyake plant, guided the students and explained what Miyake does and how manufacturing impacts all lives on a daily basis. I am incredibly thankful for Mr. Reeves and his willingness to meet with our students and give them a level of insight into manufacturing that they otherwise may have never had. #HCSProud

Students from Surgoinsville Middle School recently competed in the Northeast Tennessee District 2, Tennessee History Day 2020 Breaking Barriers competition at Lincoln Memorial University. Competitors had to choose a historical event and use primary and secondary sources to show the relationship between the topic and the theme. Students competed in three different categories as follows:

Ana Rodriguez competed in the Junior Division Individual Exhibition: Breaking Barriers: Ruby Bridges the Little Girl that Did

Scarlet Barton and Ava Collier competed in the Junior Division Group Exhibition: Breaking Barriers: The Unbreakable Code

Kaycee Bowman and Danica Brooks competed in the Junior Division Group Website Design: Breaking Barriers Amelia Earhart: The Flight that Changed Millions

We are proud to announce that each group and individual placed first in their respective categories. Students will be competing at the regional level in Knoxville on March 6th.

Way to RISE, EAGLES!!! #HCSProud

Hawkins County was recognized for its workforce development achievements over the past year at the ACT Workforce Summit in Charlotte, N.C. on Oct. 29, along with 48 other participating ACT Work Ready Communities.

The annual summit, which brings together experts in business, education, workforce and economic development, included the ACT Work Ready Communities Awards Ceremony and Recognition.

The ACT Work Ready Communities initiative empowers states, regions and counties with data, processes and tools that drive economic growth by identifying skills gaps and quantifying the skill level of their workforce. #HCSProud

Pictured from left: Hawkins County CTE Supervisor Brandon Williams, First Tennessee Development District Director of Workforce and Literacy Initiatives Lottie Ryans, Hawkins County Industrial Development Board Executive Secretary Rebecca Baker, an unidentified ACT representative and First Tennessee Development District Director of Special Projects Mark Stevans.

BGS hosted a Veterans Day program to honor our veterans and all who have served. The program featured the Cherokee High School JNROTC, the 8th Grade Tone Chimes group,and performances of "America the Beautiful" by grades K-2 and "The Brave" by grades 3-5. The guest speaker was Mr. Dennis Elkins, Commander, Post 21 American Legion, and Mr. John Stapleton shared a moving rendition of "Ragged Old Flag." All veterans present were recognized and asked to stand beside the flag representing their branch of the military. Following the program, the 5th grade served refreshments to our veterans and learned more about their experiences.
Thank you to our veterans, and to all who helped make this a memorable program! Please see the school website for videos of the program and additional photos. #HCSProud

post_text: Parents and caregivers, with the pending winter weather season fast approaching, we want to make sure you are informed of our decision making and communication process regarding school schedule changes. We will make decisions regarding the status of our schools as early as possible and will communicate such decisions in multiple ways including automated phone calls, radio station service announcements, Facebook and Twitter posts, and website updates. We ask that as parents and caregivers you develop plans for the children in your care should we experience schedule changes, including delayed starts and school closures, due to inclement weather.

post_text: Students in Mrs. Davis’s ELA classes learned about Literal and Nonliteral language. They worked together in groups to solve challenges to try and breakout and save the jewels.
